we.2: As a Mac user myself, I've tested a ton of the best VPNs on macOS. This personal experience, alongside our rigorous VPN testing process, means that I can give you first-hand advice on which VPN is best for your Mac. We focus on privacy first and foremost, but also prioritize ease of use, website and streaming unblocking, connection speeds and, of course, value for money.

we.3: Find out more about how we test, analyze, and rate.

we.4: ✅ You want a VPN that can do it all: In every area we test, NordVPN is near, or at the very top of the class. Privacy is excellent, it's great for streaming, and the apps are fairly easy to use.

we.5: ExpressVPN's connections speeds have improved since we last tested it, jumping up to about 900 Mbps on our 1 Gbps line. This is fractionally less than NordVPN and Surfshark, but you won't notice it.

we.6: How we test the best Mac VPN services

we.7: Knowing how we test VPNs is obviously important, and you can check out a full breakdown of our testing methods – but here's the quick version.

we.8: For a start, we never take the claims of providers at face value. We always put them to the test for ourselves with our dedicated in-house VPN team who love getting hands-on. In fact we test every six months so you can be sure our verdicts are up to date with the latest versions of each VPN.

we.9: Once we sign up for a VPN plan we install it on a range of devices, including Macs, and then put it through its paces. While using the VPN we'll evaluate the performance and ease of use and investigate any questions that arise. We're not afraid to dig into source code and get our hands dirty.

we.10: Streaming performance is also a big part of using a VPN and we don't skimp on testing here either.  We test each VPN with all the major streaming platforms and with Netflix in particular very fussy when it comes to VPNs, we test it each month.

we.11: You'll also find restrictions like server locations, connection speed, and data caps on many providers. Our top pick is Proton VPN Free, but we'd still recommend making the most of a paid provider's 30-day money-back guarantee over using a free service.

we.12: The good news is there's a huge amount to choose from, and we think the five on this page are the absolute cream of the crop.

we.13: However, the anonymity a VPN provides is attractive to those breaking the law. All we can say is that we do not condone any unlawful usage of VPNs, and encourage our readers to make the most of what they can provide within the confines of the law.

we.14: We test and review VPN services in the context of legal recreational uses. For example: 1. Accessing a service from another country (subject to the terms and conditions of that service). 2. Protecting your online security and strengthening your online privacy when abroad. We do not support or condone the illegal or malicious use of VPN services. Consuming pirated content that is paid-for is neither endorsed nor approved by Future Publishing.

we.15: We check over 250 million products every day for the best prices

only.0: ❌ You want unlimited simultaneous connections: Despite a recent upgrade, NordVPN still only allows 10 devices to run at the same time. Surfshark and Private Internet Access are unlimited here.

only.1: For even more protection, ExpressVPN employs TrustedServer technology that includes RAM-only servers and the entire software stack being reinstalled on every server at boot. ExpressVPN servers do not store any of your data, and once your session comes to an end, there’s virtually no record of it whatsoever.

only.2: Excellent across the board, with only a couple of niche Netflix libraries unavailable

only.4: Unlike its rivals, Proton VPN doesn't hold back on its Mac version and the only thing it misses out on here is split tunneling (available on the Windows app), but it makes up for that by providing support for an extra protocol – IKEv2, besides the usual WireGuard and OpenVPN.

only.5: A unique ad blocker that goes by the name of NetShield protects your Mac from malware found in images, scripts, and other resources on the world wide web. That said, this feature is only available to users of the paid plans. If you’re on the free plan, the standard no-ads policy of ProtonVPN will have to make do.

only.6: Decent article, but live chat is only 9-5, and the articles can be tricky to navigate

only.7: Another thing it has over the competition is a court-proven no-logs policy. Not once, but twice has PIA been taken to court to provide information on its users, and both times it had nothing to offer. This is something only shared by ExpressVPN on this list – although this doesn't mean the other providers aren't to be trusted.

only.8: Privacy – When making your choice, privacy should always come first – even if you're only planning on streaming overseas Netflix. There are many great services that have been audited and offer zero-logging policies, so there's no need to make sacrifices in this area.

only.9: Price – Finally, and most importantly for many, is price. Most VPNs cost between $3-5 a month if you choose the longest plan possible, and my #1 Mac VPN NordVPN fits neatly into this category. Others, like ExpressVPN, are slightly more expensive – in this case, it's worth it if you value a slick, simple interface that makes everything super easy. Others still drop near the $2-a-month mark – although the only providers at this price I'd truly recommend are Surfshark and Private Internet Access.

only.10: Macs are great at stopping malicious software getting into your computer, but they can't do anything once your data has left. A VPN is the only way to do that.

other.0: For example, you can have a browsing preset that maximizes security while browsing, with ad and malware blocking. On other occasions, you can prioritize download speeds and then have a different preset to go along with those settings – lots to play around with and is much welcome.

other.1: As the best Netflix VPN, NordVPN gives you unrestricted access to every Netflix library in the world, including niche locations like Japan. Not just that, it runs smoothly with all other popular streaming sites as well, including Disney Plus, Amazon Prime Video, and BBC iPlayer.

other.2: ❌ You like to tinker with settings: ExpressVPN has a few tweaks you can make, but its focus on simplicity and usability means that other more techy providers may offer more for the expert.

other.3: Surfshark provides exceptional value for money, with unlimited simultaneous connections, industry-leading speeds, and well-rounded security measures. It's very well suited for those who want to access global Netflix libraries and other streaming sites. For the price, you can't go wrong.

other.4: Surfshark also provides another layer on anonymity via its Incogni service. This sees the company request data brokers, such as those dealing in marketing data, recruitment data, people search sites, and more, to delete any data they have on you. All you have to do is fill out a form and give Incogni permission to reach out to data brokers on your behalf. This shows how dedicated Surfshark is to user privacy – although you will have to sign up separately.

other.5: Proton VPN boasts excellent privacy features, and aims to offer a more security focused experience than other services. That doesn't mean it's all work and no play, though – it's great for streaming and torrenting too. However, its high price may put some users off.

other.6: It doesn't sacrifice any usability for that though, and it's also a very powerful streaming VPN. It unblocks all popular Netflix libraries, including some hard-to-crack countries like Japan, and tons of other streaming sites too.

other.7: A unique ad blocker that goes by the name of NetShield protects your Mac from malware found in images, scripts, and other resources on the world wide web. That said, this feature is only available to users of the paid plans. If you’re on the free plan, the standard no-ads policy of ProtonVPN will have to make do.

other.8: ✅ You're a power user: With more customization options than any other VPN on this page, PIA is perfect for experts

other.9: Another thing it has over the competition is a court-proven no-logs policy. Not once, but twice has PIA been taken to court to provide information on its users, and both times it had nothing to offer. This is something only shared by ExpressVPN on this list – although this doesn't mean the other providers aren't to be trusted.

other.10: Overall, PIA is one of the most capable Mac VPN apps I've tested, and unlike some other providers, it doesn't make compromises on macOS compared to Windows. If you'll use the features at your disposal, go for it – if not, pick up a different VPN.

other.11: On the other, many VPNs have apps available in the Apple App Store. Here, you can install the app, accept the same permissions and you're away. In either case, after that stage you'll need to input your login details and get covered.

other.12: Are Mac VPNs different to other VPNs?

if.0: My top three choice are just below, but if you want to read about each of the featured providers, keep scrolling to our in-depth analyses of all five.

if.1: 2. ExpressVPN – The best Mac VPN for beginnersIf you prefer a simpler experience, ExpressVPN is the perfect choice. It's super secure, but make staying private online as easy as possible with simple, robust apps. It includes tons of extras as standard, like a password manager and a personal data removal tool, and prices start at $4.99 per month (around $149 all-in). You can also test it out with its 30-day money-back guarantee.

if.4: Recent updates the to service have addressed my main concerns with NordVPN. You can now run the app on 10 devices simultaneously – up from six – and the server spread has increased to a massive 111 countries. This takes NordVPN ahead of its closest rivals, ExpressVPN and Surfshark, and if I'm honest, it's not a difficult choice to place it first in this guide.

if.6: ✅ You want everything on offer for one price: ExpressVPN isn't cheap, but on the basic subscription you get almost everything on offer. If you'll use it all, it works out much better value than NordVPN's respective plan.

if.8: ❌ You want a cheap VPN: If you just want a VPN, rivals Surfshark and Private Internet Access cost a lot less.

if.9: Both ExpressVPN’s Windows and Mac apps are very similar in how they look and function. However, the Mac version doesn’t have split tunneling. On the bright side, it provides the Threat Manager and the malware and tracking blocker, both of which are offerings omitted from its Windows app. It's also the best iPhone VPN on the market, so if you have multiple Apple devices, it's well worth considering.

if.12: ❌ You only want to torrent: Surfshark supports torrenting on its service, but if that’s your major use case, PIA or ExpressVPN is better suited for you.

if.13: ❌ You’re a Windows user: If you also happen to have a device running Windows, I found a minor issue with the kill switch. This doesn't affect Macs, however.

if.14: If you want even more anonymity then Surfshark has you covered too. Subscribers get access to its Alternative ID tool, a system that lets you randomly create an email address and identity for signing up to services online. You need never risk your personal details or real email address again. If you sign up for the Alternative Number paid add-on then you can even set up a fake number that actually works on your phone!

if.17: ❌ You want access to Japanese Netflix: If your watchlist is majorly the Japanese Netflix library, you’re better off with NordVPN or ExpressVPN.

if.18: A unique ad blocker that goes by the name of NetShield protects your Mac from malware found in images, scripts, and other resources on the world wide web. That said, this feature is only available to users of the paid plans. If you’re on the free plan, the standard no-ads policy of ProtonVPN will have to make do.

if.21: ❌ You have a gigabit connection: Topping out at around 320 Mbps means PIA could slow you down if you have an ultra-fast connection.

if.22: Private Internet Access is a favorite with the techy crowd, and offers a huge amount of customization. If you're looking to configure port forwarding and want full control over your Mac VPN, it's the one to go for – but for beginners, I'd suggest ExpressVPN or Surfshark.

if.23: Private Internet Access is a stalwart in the VPN game, and it offers one of the most powerful VPNs on Mac that I've tested. What's more, it rivals Surfshark as one of the best-value VPNs around – there's a whole lot of value here if you're going to use it.

if.24: It's not all good with Private Internet Access, though. Connection speeds are one of its downfalls, and in my testing it topped out at a below-average 320 Mbps. Of course, if your connection doesn't go that fast, that's nothing to worry about. But, if you pay for an uncontested gigabit line, you'll likely want to sign up to a provider that can match that.

if.25: Also, PIA's Mac apps are quite complex, due to how much functionality is packed in there. This won't be an issue if you're willing to learn the software and configure it the way you like, but if you're looking for a simple one-and-done experience, it's probably not for you.

if.26: Overall, PIA is one of the most capable Mac VPN apps I've tested, and unlike some other providers, it doesn't make compromises on macOS compared to Windows. If you'll use the features at your disposal, go for it – if not, pick up a different VPN.

if.27: Privacy – When making your choice, privacy should always come first – even if you're only planning on streaming overseas Netflix. There are many great services that have been audited and offer zero-logging policies, so there's no need to make sacrifices in this area.

if.28: Usability – The app interface is a very important part of a VPN – if you hate the experience, you're unlikely to use a VPN as much as you might like to. This is very subjective, but if you go for a more complex VPN like Proton VPN or Private Internet Access, it's worth bearing in mind you'll have 30 days to claim a refund if you don't get on with the software.

if.29: Price – Finally, and most importantly for many, is price. Most VPNs cost between $3-5 a month if you choose the longest plan possible, and my #1 Mac VPN NordVPN fits neatly into this category. Others, like ExpressVPN, are slightly more expensive – in this case, it's worth it if you value a slick, simple interface that makes everything super easy. Others still drop near the $2-a-month mark – although the only providers at this price I'd truly recommend are Surfshark and Private Internet Access.

if.30: From my testing, I rate NordVPN the highest when it comes to VPNs for Mac. However, if you're looking to save some money, Surfshark offers a comparable service for a considerably cheaper price, and if you're a beginner looking for a super simple experience, ExpressVPN will be perfect.

if.31: If you're not careful, you could risk having your data compromised – so make sure to make your choice from our recommendations.

if.32: All Macs have the functionality to support VPN usage, but Apple doesn't provide it's own VPN software. Therefore, if you want real privacy, you'll have to use a third-party service.

if.33: Getting a Mac VPN is as simple – if not simpler – than on a Windows device. Firstly it's a good idea to sign up to a VPN plan, and then you'll have two options.

if.34: In practise, though, there's very little a quality Mac VPN can't do compared to a VPN on Windows, especially if you pick from my hand-tested selection here.

when.1: Although Macs have better built-in protection than Windows devices, when it comes to online privacy and avoiding surveillance, the best place to start is to use one of the best Mac VPNs. It's also very affordable – well worth considering.

when.12: Mo is VPN Editor at Tom's Guide. you can.5: ✅ You want to pick and choose your extra features: NordVPN offers its VPN with a couple of extras for an affordable price – but you can tack on tons of extras on higher-tier plans.

you can.6: For example, you can have a browsing preset that maximizes security while browsing, with ad and malware blocking. On other occasions, you can prioritize download speeds and then have a different preset to go along with those settings – lots to play around with and is much welcome.

you can.7: Recent updates the to service have addressed my main concerns with NordVPN. You can now run the app on 10 devices simultaneously – up from six – and the server spread has increased to a massive 111 countries. This takes NordVPN ahead of its closest rivals, ExpressVPN and Surfshark, and if I'm honest, it's not a difficult choice to place it first in this guide.

you can.8: ✅ You want a VPN you can set and forget:

you can.9: ❌ You like to tinker with settings: ExpressVPN has a few tweaks you can make, but its focus on simplicity and usability means that other more techy providers may offer more for the expert.

you can.10: In my hands-on ExpressVPN review, the British Virgin Islands-based provider came out as one of the very best services available, and on Mac the answer is no different. With powerful encryption, a rock-solid kill switch and an auto-connect feature, you can rest assured that your browsing history or real location will never be left vulnerable.

you can.11: You can now log in with the same ExpressVPN account on 8 devices simultaneously. This number was previously 5, so the jump is commendable, but rivals like Surfshark and PIA come with unlimited simultaneous connections, and at a lower price point. However, I'm glad to see ExpressVPN pushing to offer more value to customers.

you can.12: ✅ You want unlimited simultaneous connections: You can cover any number of devices with just one Surfshark subscription, including your family members and friends and then some.

you can.13: Surfshark provides exceptional value for money, with unlimited simultaneous connections, industry-leading speeds, and well-rounded security measures. It's very well suited for those who want to access global Netflix libraries and other streaming sites. For the price, you can't go wrong.

you can.14: However, the app window isn’t resizable, nor is the kill switch status shown on the home screen, both of which are a little annoying, especially when you consider that it’s not the case on Surfshark’s Windows app. But the Mac app shines through with its auto-connect functionality – something the Windows app doesn’t have. You can rest assured that you’ll be connected to a secure Surfshark server at all times.

you can.15: If you want even more anonymity then Surfshark has you covered too. Subscribers get access to its Alternative ID tool, a system that lets you randomly create an email address and identity for signing up to services online. You need never risk your personal details or real email address again. If you sign up for the Alternative Number paid add-on then you can even set up a fake number that actually works on your phone!

you can.16: ✅ You want a VPN you can trust with your life:

you can.17: In my Private Internet Access review, I found the provider goes beyond the basics with an advanced implementation of split tunnelling – you can set up specific rules for apps and certain situations – and those looking for a torrenting VPN will appreciate the inclusion of port forwarding. In fact, it tops my guide on services to torrent with.

you can.18: Knowing how we test VPNs is obviously important, and you can check out a full breakdown of our testing methods – but here's the quick version.

you can.19: For a start, we never take the claims of providers at face value. We always put them to the test for ourselves with our dedicated in-house VPN team who love getting hands-on. In fact we test every six months so you can be sure our verdicts are up to date with the latest versions of each VPN.

you can.20: All these providers offer 256-AES encryption, and are independently audited, meaning you can trust them to anonymise your connections effectively, whatever you're browsing. Plus, they're some of the best services for unblocking streaming sites, too.

you can.21: On the one hand, you can download the VPN software directly from the VPN provider's website. You'll end up with a .DMG file, which you can then install. In the process you'll likely have to give the software permissions.

you can.22: On the other, many VPNs have apps available in the Apple App Store. Here, you can install the app, accept the same permissions and you're away. In either case, after that stage you'll need to input your login details and get covered.

your choice.0: Privacy – When making your choice, privacy should always come first – even if you're only planning on streaming overseas Netflix. There are many great services that have been audited and offer zero-logging policies, so there's no need to make sacrifices in this area.

your choice.1: If you're not careful, you could risk having your data compromised – so make sure to make your choice from our recommendations.

delete.0: Surfshark also provides another layer on anonymity via its Incogni service. This sees the company request data brokers, such as those dealing in marketing data, recruitment data, people search sites, and more, to delete any data they have on you. All you have to do is fill out a form and give Incogni permission to reach out to data brokers on your behalf. This shows how dedicated Surfshark is to user privacy – although you will have to sign up separately.

removal.0: 2. ExpressVPN – The best Mac VPN for beginnersIf you prefer a simpler experience, ExpressVPN is the perfect choice. It's super secure, but make staying private online as easy as possible with simple, robust apps. It includes tons of extras as standard, like a password manager and a personal data removal tool, and prices start at $4.99 per month (around $149 all-in). You can also test it out with its 30-day money-back guarantee.

policy.0: The unique Meshnet feature works like a LAN network, allowing you to securely connect up to 60 devices directly. This eliminates the need to ever send files to the server cloud, making gaming or collaborating with your buddies and file sharing more secure. This, coupled with an independently audited no-logs policy and in-built antivirus, makes NordVPN a complete security suite adept on all counts.

policy.1: A complete package with a verified no-logs policy, reliable encryption, and a built-in antivirus

policy.2: ✅ You want class-leading privacy and security: ExpressVPN provides comprehensive VPN protection, with an independently audited no-logs policy, ad and malware blockers

policy.3: The Threat Manager is a unique ExpressVPN feature that blocks apps and websites on your Mac from tracking your activity, let alone relaying it to third parties. A strict no-logs policy and class-leading encryption with secure DNS and P2P support on all servers make ExpressVPN one of the most secure VPNs on the market right now.

policy.4: Well known as a very private VPN, Proton VPN delivers excellent protection for its users across the board. Fully audited apps, an excellent no-logging policy and full AES-256 encryption alongside more unusual features like Tor over VPN and its rock-solid Secure Core servers make it a good choice for anyone looking for a properly secure Mac VPN.

policy.5: A unique ad blocker that goes by the name of NetShield protects your Mac from malware found in images, scripts, and other resources on the world wide web. That said, this feature is only available to users of the paid plans. If you’re on the free plan, the standard no-ads policy of ProtonVPN will have to make do.

policy.7: ✅ You want to use your VPN on tons of devices: PIA's unlimited device policy means one subscription goes further.

policy.8: Another thing it has over the competition is a court-proven no-logs policy. Not once, but twice has PIA been taken to court to provide information on its users, and both times it had nothing to offer. This is something only shared by ExpressVPN on this list – although this doesn't mean the other providers aren't to be trusted.

you choose.0: Price – Finally, and most importantly for many, is price. Most VPNs cost between $3-5 a month if you choose the longest plan possible, and my #1 Mac VPN NordVPN fits neatly into this category. Others, like ExpressVPN, are slightly more expensive – in this case, it's worth it if you value a slick, simple interface that makes everything super easy. Others still drop near the $2-a-month mark – although the only providers at this price I'd truly recommend are Surfshark and Private Internet Access.

encryption.0: As the best-known VPN around, it's no surprise to see NordVPN crop up as the best Mac VPN. Alongside a full security suite, it comes with its own super-fast encryption protocol, that topped my speed tests at over 950 Mbps.

encryption.1: In my hands-on NordVPN review, I found that it offers all the basics, like powerful encryption and multiple protocols, but it also delivers a few features that aren't available with rivals ExpressVPN and Surfshark. The unique 'Onion over VPN' setting routes you through the Tor network, which sacrifices speed for unrivaled privacy.

encryption.5: With full support for WireGuard, OpenVPN, and IKEv2, industry-standard AES-256 encryption, and a few extra features like split tunnelling and Double Hop, along with Clean Web 2.0 ad and malware blocking, it's a complete package. The simple, friendly Mac interface also makes these features easy to use, and just like ExpressVPN, it's a great option for first-timers.
